revision.text:
'''James William Dawes''' (January 8, 1844{{spaced ndash}}October 8, 1918) was a [[Republican Party (U.S.)|Republican]] [[Nebraska]] [[politician]]. He served as the [[List of Governors of Nebraska|sixth]] [[Governor of Nebraska|Governor]] of Nebraska from 1883 to 1887. He was born in [[McConnelsville]], [[Ohio]]. He was the great-grandson of [[William Dawes]], a first cousin of [[Rufus R. Dawes]], and a first cousin once removed of [[Charles G. Dawes]]. Dawes attended [[Western Reserve Academy]] in Ohio and The Milwaukee Business College. He studied law in his cousin's law firm and was [[admitted to the bar]] in 1871.{{cite web|title=James W. Dawes|url=http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_nebraska/col2-content/main-content-list/title_dawes_james.html|publisher=National Governors Association|accessdate=16 September 2012}} Dawes married his cousin, Francis Anna Dawes, in 1871. She died in 1909. ==Career== After relocating to [[Crete, Nebraska]], Dawes worked in the mercantile business and opened a law practice.{{cite web|title=James W. Dawes|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rWkP0DM_upwC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=nebraska+governor+Robert+Wilkinson+Furnas&source=bl&ots=n5zrZY7rsp&sig=tHM_nvIw7QtKf5cOHDFSzN3KfcQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lUxVUOGIHsm_2QXe-oDIBg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=nebraska%20governor%20Robert%20Wilkinson%20Furnas&f=false|publisher=The Encyclopedia of Nebraska|accessdate=16 September 2012}} He was a delegate to the State Constitutional Convention in 1875 and a member of [[Nebraska State Senate]] in 1877.{{cite web|title=James W. Dawes|url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/davis-dawsey.html|publisher=The Political Graveyard|accessdate=16 September 2012}} Dawes was a chairman of the Republican State Central Committee from 1876 to 1882. Dawes was elected [[Governor of Nebraska]] in 1882, and was reelected to a second term in 1884.{{cite web|url= http://nebraskaccess.ne.gov/pastnebraskagovernors.asp |title= Who were the former Governors of Nebraska?|publisher= Nebraska Access|accessdate= September 15, 2012}} He later served as [[paymaster]] for the United States Army, working in Cuba and the Philippines.{{cite web|url= http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_nebraska/col2-content/main-content-list/title_dawes_james.html |title= Nebraska Governor James William Dawes|publisher= National Governors Association |accessdate= September 15, 2012}} Dawes served on the [[Doane College]] [[board of trustees]] for thirty-seven years. ==Death== Dawes died on October 8, 1918, at the age of seventy-four, in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]].[http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/research/public/state_governors/dawes.pdf Gov. James W. Dawes papers] at the [[Nebraska State Historical Society]]. Retrieved 2009-07-06. He is interred at Forest Home Cemetery, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.{{cite web|title=James W. Dawes|url=http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_nebraska/col2-content/main-content-list/title_dawes_james.html|publisher=National Governors Association|accessdate=16 September 2012}} ==Legacy== [[Dawes County, Nebraska]] was named in Dawes' honor.{{cite web|url= http://www.epodunk.com/cgi-bin/genInfo.php?locIndex=22380 |title= Profile for Dawes County, Nebraska, NE|publisher= ePodunk |accessdate= September 15, 2012}} Between 1885 and 1890, Dawes' portrait was painted in Omaha by artist [[Herbert A. Collins]].Biography of Herbert Alexander Collins, by Alfred W. Collins, February 1975, 4 pages typed, in the possession of Collins' great-great grand-daughter, D. Dahl of Tacoma, WA ==See also== * [[List of Governors of Nebraska]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{cite web |title=The Political Graveyard |work=Dawes, James William |url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/davis-dawsey.html#RDH0Q2XRW|accessdate=January 3, 2006}} * [http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_nebraska/col2-content/main-content-list/title_dawes_james.html National Governors Association]
